structured_info.title_cn: 联网和自动驾驶车辆专用车道的全网安全影响
structured_info.title_en: Network-wide safety impacts of dedicated lanes for connected and autonomous vehicles
structured_info.abstract: Cooperative, Connected and Automated Mobility (CCAM) enabled by Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs) has potential to change future transport systems. The findings from previous studies suggest that these technologies will improve traffic flow, reduce travel time and delays. Furthermore, these CAVs will be safer compared to existing vehicles. As these vehicles may have the ability to travel at a higher speed and with shorter headways, it has been argued that infrastructure-based measures are required to optimise traffic flow and road user comfort. One of these measures is the use of a dedicated lane for CAVs on urban highways and arterials and constitutes the focus of this research. As the potential impact on safety is unclear, the present study aims to evaluate the safety impacts of dedicated lanes for CAVs. A calibrated and validated microsimulation model developed in AIMSUN was used to simulate and produce safety results. These results were analysed with the help of the Surrogate Safety Assessment Model (SSAM).
structured_info.methodology: A calibrated and validated microsimulation model developed in AIMSUN was used to simulate and produce safety results. These results were analysed with the help of the Surrogate Safety Assessment Model (SSAM). The model includes human-driven vehicles (HDVs), 1st generation and 2nd generation autonomous vehicles (AVs) with different sets of parameters leading to different movement behaviour.
structured_info.conclusion: The simulation results revealed that with dedicated lane, the combination of 40-40-20 (i.e., 40% human-driven, 40% 1st generation AVs, 20% 2nd generation AVs) could be the optimum MPR for CAVs to achieve the best safety benefits. The findings in this study provide useful insight into the safety impacts of dedicated lanes for CAVs and could be used to develop a policy support tool for local authorities and practitioners.

analysis.Overview: The paper evaluates the safety impacts of dedicated lanes for connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) using a microsimulation model. It focuses on how dedicated lanes affect traffic conflicts and crash rates under varying market penetration rates (MPRs) of CAVs.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the transition phase where human-driven vehicles (HDVs) and CAVs will coexist on roads.
The study aims to understand the safety implications of dedicated lanes for CAVs, which are proposed to optimize traffic flow and reduce interactions between HDVs and CAVs.
The authors argue that dedicated lanes are necessary to mitigate potential crash risks during the early stages of CAV deployment.
The study connects the specific problem of mixed traffic safety to broader challenges in transportation systems, emphasizing the need for infrastructure adaptations.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering, traffic safety, and urban planning disciplines.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include dedicated lanes for CAVs, traffic microsimulation, and surrogate safety measures.
The logical relationship involves using microsimulation to model traffic conflicts, which are then analyzed to estimate crash rates.
Key assumptions include the behavior parameters of 1st and 2nd generation CAVs and the effectiveness of dedicated lanes in reducing conflicts.
The paper contributes a methodological framework for assessing safety impacts of CAV dedicated lanes, filling a gap in existing literature.
Methodology: The study uses AIMSUN microsimulation software to model traffic scenarios and SSAM to analyze conflicts.
The methodology is novel in combining microsimulation with probabilistic crash estimation, though it relies on assumptions due to lack of real-world CAV data.
Data sources include a calibrated Manchester road network model, with traffic counts and journey times for validation.
Experimental design includes 10 replications per scenario to account for stochastic variability, using TTC and PET as evaluation metrics.
The research follows a simulation-based paradigm, focusing on surrogate safety measures to infer real-world safety impacts.
Results: Key results show a 53-58% reduction in traffic conflicts with dedicated lanes at high CAV MPRs and up to 48% reduction in estimated crashes.
Results are significant for policy-making but are limited by simulation assumptions and the need for real-world validation.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The argument structure progresses from problem identification to methodology development, results presentation, and policy implications.
Key steps include literature review, microsimulation setup, conflict analysis, and crash estimation.
Strengths include comprehensive scenario testing; weaknesses include reliance on simulated data and assumptions about CAV behavior.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths include a detailed microsimulation approach and innovative use of surrogate safety measures.
Limitations involve the lack of real-world CAV data and potential biases in conflict detection.
The theoretical paradigm constrains conclusions to simulated environments, requiring cautious interpretation for real-world applications.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper positions itself within ongoing discourse on CAV integration and safety, using technical terminology and empirical results to build authority.
Citations are used to justify methodological choices and assumptions, aligning with established research in traffic safety.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Conclusions highlight the safety benefits of dedicated lanes at optimal CAV MPRs (40-40-20 mix).
Future research should address real-world validation and behavioral adaptations of human drivers interacting with CAVs.
